post.title: You can Wget a website and add it to IPFS and it works
post.body:
The hardest thing about setting up IPFS (http://ipfs.io/docs/install/) is finding your Environment Path. In Windows just search 'PATH'.

You can Wget a website as [previous post](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1HBXiufU8RyFMREQa27yM92U329EXrfWvS/?Post:31:Mirroring+a+website+to+work+without+internet+on+ZeroNet) and then add that folder to IPFS by navigating to that folder in Command Prompt and then:

_[wget website folder]_$ **ipfs add -r .** 

Which adds the entire folder to IPFS. When you then click the hash in the _WebUI_ (Firefox add-on), the website will be live. 

Here is [Automate the Boring Stuff](http://127.0.0.1:43110/automatetheboringstuff.bit/) Zeronet and [IPFS](http://127.0.0.1:8080/ipfs/QmRNfCeLE8CXNHNMp15iraPusvbwVRMMfw7cvUxV6A2NMw/) (you need to have IPFS installed and moved to PATH, and then in Command Prompt$ **ipfs daemon**; and the file needs to be available from someone running IPFS for you to get it). 

Follow this tutorial (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8CMxDNuuAiQ).

post.title: dotbit.me
post.body: For _Namecoin_ .bit names that aren't already owned, go to https://dotbit.me/ to verify.

post.title: imdb.com's thumbnail images contain actual location data
post.body: Check before using www.imdb.com's movie images because I think they contain **actual location** data.
